abstract.text: An interaction between the user and your app involving an intent object.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object encapsulates information about a SiriKit request and your app’s response. SiriKit creates interaction objects automatically when it needs your app to respond to a specific intent, either by handling the intent or providing an error explaining why your app couldn’t handle the intent. SiriKit places the interaction in an
object that the system passes to your app at launch time. You can also create instances of this class in your app and donate relevant interactions to the system.

Donating interactions provides contextual information that might be helpful to other apps. Some system apps use donated interactions to improve search results or to anticipate user actions. For example, a ride-booking app could donate an interaction containing the user’s planned ride information. If the user subsequently uses the Maps app to search for restaurants, Maps can show relevant results near the user’s destination.
You choose which of your app’s interactions you want to donate to the system. To donate an interaction, create an instance of this class, filling it with your intent object and response, and call the
method. You can also use the methods of this class to delete interactions when they are no longer relevant.
Donate interactions only when the user initiates an interaction in your app. SiriKit already knows about interactions that it sends your app for intent handling.

abstract.text: A representation of the state of your app at a moment in time.

The direction in which information flowed to or from the device.

The unique identifier of the interaction.

The intent object that describes the user’s request.
The current state of the interaction.
The response object that your app created in response to the request.

The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
